title: A biochemical reconstitution approach to identify autophagy receptors for aggrephagy in mammalian cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
In vitro reconstitution system
Timing: 1 day
The in vitro reconstitution system is to recapitulate the recruitment of autophagosomes to protein aggregates by adding a fluorescence-labeled LC3 protein to the IBs formed by polyQ-HTT.
In vitro reconstitution.
Plate about 8 × 105 U2OS HTT-Q91-mCherry cells in a 6-cm dish. Maintain the cells in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 200 ng/mL puromycin, and 100 μg /mL hygromycin at 37°C in 5% CO2 for 12 h to allow the cells to adherence.
Note: We recommend users plate another dish of cell without expression of HTT-Q91-mCherry to prepare a control sample for the following FACS analysis. The control sample is prepared together with experimental group as the following 1c–f.
Incubate the cells with 1 μg/mL doxycycline for 24 h to induce the expression of HTT-Q91-mCherry and IBs formation.
Wash cells once with 5 mL PBS, scrape off cells with a cell scraper in 1 mL PBS, and transfer into a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube. Centrifuge at 600 × g for 5 min at 25°C to collect cells.
Add 400 μL B88 buffer plus 1% Triton X-100, 4 μL cocktail protease inhibitors (Sigma, solution), 100 U/mL DNase, and 1 U/mL RNase to the cell pellet and homogenize by passing through a 22 G needle for 10 times. (U refers to Kunitz unit here and below.).
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 8 min at 25°C, and carefully remove the supernatant.
Wash the pellet containing IBs with 1 mL B88 buffer plus 0.5% Triton X-100 and centrifuge again at 300 × g for 8 min at 25°C.
Resuspend the pellet in 400 μL B88 buffer plus 0.5% Triton X-100, 4 μL cocktail protease inhibitors, 50 U/mL DNase and divide into four equal samples (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]):

Figure 1. A scheme of major steps for the in vitro constitution system
Cells expressing mHTT IBs are lysed and centrifuged to collect IBs. Incubate the IBs with indicated proteins. Use flow cytometry to analysis IBs and quantify the LC3 (488) on IBs.
No protein added.
Add 5–10 μg/mL fluorescence-labeled LC3 protein.
Add 5–10 μg/mL fluorescence-labeled LC3 protein and 2–5 times BSA.
Add 5–10 μg/mL fluorescence-labeled LC3 protein and 2–5 times non-labeled LC3 protein. Incubate the reactions for 1 h at 30°C and protect from light.
Note: We tried a series of the concentration of fluorescence-labeled LC3 (from 0.5 μg/mL to 10 μg/mL). The different concentration only caused a variable LC3 fluorescence intensity on IBs but didn’t change the results (the fluorescent LC3 on IBs can be competed by non-fluorescent LC3 but not BSA).
Centrifuge at 1,000 × g for 5 min, wash the pellet with 500 μL PBS plus 0.5% Triton X-100 and centrifuge again.
Resuspend the pellet in 500 μL PBS for FACS analysis.
FACS analysis of LC3 specific association with IBs.
Use a pulse shape analysis (PulSA) based on flow cytometry strategy (Ramdzan et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]) to quantify the recruitment of LC3 to the IBs:
Create histograms of mCherry-A and 488-A. Use the control sample and sample ii in step 1g to dynamically modify the range by adjusting the voltage of the PMTs until the sample signal spans the full detector range.
Create a dot plot of pulse heights versus pulse widths of the mCherry.
Note: If your flow cytometry cannot collect the pulse width and height of the fluorescence, you can also use the mCherry versus FSC.
By comparing the control sample with the experimental sample, gate the unique population characteristic of IBs (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Collect data for at least 20,000 IBs.

Analyze the fluorescence of LC3 (488) on IBs.
Compare the LC3 fluorescence on IBs in four different groups from step 1g. A successful in vitro reconstitution should show no LC3 fluorescence in 1g (i), higher LC3 fluorescence in 1g (ii & iii), and lower LC3 fluorescence in 1g (iv) because of the competition by non-labeled LC3 (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Screen for candidate aggrephagy receptors
Timing: 1 day for step 3; 2–3 days for step 4
After establishing an effective in vitro reconstitution system, we divide IBs into two groups according to the LC3 fluorescence and conduct an unlabeled quantitative mass spectrometry to compare protein components enriched in two groups.
Sort IBs into two groups (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1982-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. A scheme of major steps to sort IBs
Cells expressing mHTT IBs are lysed and centrifuged to collect IBs. Incubate the IBs with fluorescent LC3. Use flow cytometry to analysis IBs and divide IBs into two groups according to the LC3 fluorescence. Conduct proteomic analysis based on mass spectrometry to identify proteins enrich in High-LC3 IBs as candidate aggrephagy receptors.
Plate U2OS HTT-Q91-mCherry cells at 2 × 106 cells / dish in four 10-cm dishes. After 12 h, add 1 μg/mL doxycycline for 24 h to induce the expression of HTT-Q91-mCherry and IBs formation.
Wash cells once with 5 mL PBS and scrape off cells with a cell scraper in 3 mL PBS for each dish. Transfer cell suspension into a 15 mL centrifuge tube. Centrifuge at 600 × g for 5 min at 25°C to collect cells.
Add 1.6 mL B88 buffer plus 1% Triton X-100, 16 μL cocktail protease inhibitors (Sigma, solution), 100 U/mL DNase, and 1 U/mL RNase to the cell pellet and homogenize by passing through a 22 G needle for 10 times.

Centrifuge at 300 × g for 8 min at 25°C, and carefully remove the supernatant.
Wash the pellet containing IBs with 1 mL B88 buffer plus 0.5% Triton X-100 and centrifuge again at 300 × g for 8 min at 25°C.
Resuspend the pellets in 1.6 mL B88 buffer plus 0.5% Triton X-100, 16 μL cocktail protease inhibitors, and 50 U/mL DNase.
Add 0.5–1 μg/mL fluorescence-labeled LC3 protein to solution and incubate for 1 h at 30°C in dark.
Note: The sorting steps need a larger reaction system than FACS analysis in step 1. To save protein, we used a lower concentration of fluorescence-labeled LC3 compared to step 1g.
Centrifuge at 1,000 × g for 8 min, wash the pellet with 500 μL PBS plus 1% Triton X-100 and centrifuge again.
Resuspend the pellet in 2 mL PBS for sorting two groups of IBs with flow cytometry:
Gate the population of IBs.
Divide the IBs into two groups according to the LC3 fluorescence on them: High- LC3 IBs and Low-LC3 IBs.
Note: The “High” and “Low” are the relative fluorescent intensity of LC3 under a specific fluorescent intensity of IBs. You can mark the medians of LC3 intensity (488) under several IBs intensity (mCherry) and join these points into a line. Signals above this line are High-LC3 IBs and vice versa. Gate farther away the line will get more variability but waste more samples.
Sort 1 million IB particles for each group.
The IB solutions were centrifuged at 3,000 × g for 30 min.
Add 25 μL Aggregates Loading buffer to the IB pellets and boil at 100°C for 10 min.
Load all samples into 10% PAGE gel and conduct SDS-PAGE as conventional methods (a constant voltage of 80 V for stacking gel and 120 V for separating gel).

Note: Leave one lane empty between the two samples and the SDS-PAGE can be finished when the bromophenol blue enters 3–4 cm into the separating gel to ease the following processing.
Stain the gel with Simply Blue (Invitrogen) as the instruction manual (https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/simplyblue_man.pdf[href=https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/simplyblue_man.pdf]).
Note: It is good for the flow sorter to be able to collect the pulse width and height of the fluorescence (e.g., BD FACSAria SORP). Otherwise, a BD influx also works in a two-color gate mode.
Mass-spectrometry-based label-free quantification.
Note: The reagents in this workflow should use mass spectrometry grade reagents.
Excise the whole lanes above the bromophenol blue from the gel, each lane was split into three samples of equal length to increase the number of protein identifications, then cut the gel into small pieces less than 1 cubic millimeter.
Incubate the gel particles with 1 mL decolorizing buffer for 1 h, then remove the supernatant (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). Repeat decolorizing step twice to fully remove the Simple Blue dye.the
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1982-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Gel particles destaining and drying
(A) The destaining step to remove the Simple Blue dye in gel particles with destaining buffer.
(B) Drying step to dry the gel particles with ACN.
Caution: ACN is toxic to inhale and highly flammable, all operations in this step should be done in a fume hood.
Add 1 mL 100% ACN and incubate for 10 min to dry the gel particles, then remove the supernatant (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). Repeat the drying step twice.
Add reduction buffer to submerge the gel particles and incubated at 55°C for 30 min for cysteine reduction, then remove the supernatant and dry the gel particles with 1 mL 100% ACN (repeat drying step twice) as previously described in step 4c.

Add alkylation buffer to submerge the gel particles and incubate in dark for 30 min for cysteine alkylation. Then, remove the supernatant and dry the gel particles with 1 mL 100% ACN (repeat drying step twice) as previously described in step 4c.
Add 100 μL digestion buffer to each sample and replenish 25 mM ammonium bicarbonate solution to submerge the gel particles. Incubate at 37°C for 12 h. After incubation, transfer the supernatant to a new EP tube.
Recover the digested peptides from the gel using 200 μL extraction buffer nd incubate for 1 h at 37°C. After incubation, transfer the supernatant to merge with the supernatant from step 4f. Repeat recovering step twice.
Evaporate the solvent of the recovered solution by vacuum centrifugation.
Reconstitute the recovered peptides in 25 μL 0.1% formic acid for LC/MS analysis.
Online-desalt and analyze the recovered peptides using an UltiMate 3000 RSLCnano System (Thermo Scientific, USA) which was directly interfaced with a Thermo Q Exactive mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA).
Note: Other Liquid Chromatograph Mass Spectrometers (e.g., LTQ Orbitrap velos, Orbitrap Fusion Tribrid, Orbitrap Fusion LUMOS, Synapt G2, etc) can also be used.
Separate peptide with UltiMate 3000 RSLCnano System using a 120-min gradient with 0.30 μL/min flow rate.
Note: Mobile phase A is consisted of 5% acetonitrile, 95% water, and 0.1% formic acid. Mobile phase B is consisted of 80% acetonitrile, 20% water, and 0.1% formic acid. The analytical column is a home-made fused silica capillary column (75 μm ID, 150 mm length; Upchurch) packed with C18 resin (300 Å, 5 μm; Varian).
Acquire the MS/MS spectra with the Thermo Q Exactive mass spectrometer operated in the data-dependent acquisition mode using Xcalibur 2.8 software.

Note: Use a single full-scan mass spectrum in the orbitrap (300–1,800 m/z, 70,000 resolution) followed by 20 loop count cycle of data-dependent MS/MS scans at 27% normalized collision energy (HCD).
Search the MS/MS spectra from each LC-MS/MS run against the Human Proteome (Uniprot) database using an in-house Proteome Discoverer 1.4 software (Thermo Fisher Scientific).
Note: Set the search criteria as follows: Enzyme: Trypsin (Specific), carbamidomethylation (C): fixed modifications, the oxidation (M): variable modification, precursor ion mass tolerances: 20 ppm for all MS acquired in an orbitrap mass analyzer, fragment ion mass tolerance: 0.02 Da for all MS2 spectra acquired, false discovery rate (FDR) was calculated using percolator and the cut-of was set as 1%.
Perform Relative protein quantification with Proteome Discoverer software according to manufacturer’s instructions on the reporter ion peak area per peptide (https://files.mtstatic.com/site_13984/6869/0?Expires=1659082727&Signature=qF2MFsBJLzTj7dbHtSdvLowrRljjUiLLpoRwsxil∼7wDLwVlMePyhYfMiU4OPDowP4rHDNRB5AUacLiw7bPZnfqQr6lZti7j3v5PzT5FswwDHTvOTEwmNbA72nyka5FOelaFqUozrf4dHbNnGee-Hc∼FdNawMgg88Sbc3VHPss8_&Key-Pair-Id=APKAJ5Y6AV4GI7A555NA[href=https://files.mtstatic.com/site_13984/6869/0?Expires=1659082727&Signature=qF2MFsBJLzTj7dbHtSdvLowrRljjUiLLpoRwsxil%7E7wDLwVlMePyhYfMiU4OPDowP4rHDNRB5AUacLiw7bPZnfqQr6lZti7j3v5PzT5FswwDHTvOTEwmNbA72nyka5FOelaFqUozrf4dHbNnGee-Hc%7EFdNawMgg88Sbc3VHPss8_&Key-Pair-Id=APKAJ5Y6AV4GI7A555NA]).
Note: Other software such as Maxquant can also be used.
Use the peak area for protein abundance comparison between the High-LC3 IBs and Low-LC3 IBs. We recommend to choose the proteins whose ratio in High-LC3 IBs/Low-LC3 IBs > 2 and the p-value < 0.05 (two-tailed t test from three independent experiments) as candidate receptors for further study.
Generate the candidate receptor plasmid library
Timing: 1–2 weeks
Once finding out new candidate receptors enriched in High-LC3 IBs, prepare plasmids expressing these proteins for further study. The gene can be cloned from cDNA or directly purchased from plasmid suppliers (e.g., Addgene and Sino Biological). We prefer to tag the candidate receptors with HA and insert them into the FUGW backbone. Other tags and vectors can also be used. In the following steps, we take the HA-tagged candidate receptors as examples.
Autophagosome recruitment assay
Timing: 3 days
Immunofluorescence assay.
Plate U2OS cells on coverslips in 24-well plate and culture for 12 h to 60%–70% confluency.

Transfect cells with Q103-HTT-BFP together with an empty plasmid or plasmids expressing candidate receptors.
Dilute 0.2 μg Q103-HTT-BFP and 0.3 μg empty / candidate receptors plasmids into 50 μL DMEM and gently pipette up and down to mix.
Add 1 μL X-tremeGENE DNA transfection reagent to the diluted DNA and gently mix.
Incubate for 20 min at 25°C.
Add transfection complex to the cells in a dropwise manner.
Note: Other transfection reagents such as Lipofectamine 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen), and Neofect Transfectoion Reagent (GenePharma) can also be used.
24 h after transfection, treat cells with 0.5 μg/mL Bafilomycin A1 for 2 h to accumulate the autophagosomes in cells.
Dissolve digitonin in ddH2O to prepare 50 mg/mL stock solution. The stock solution can be stored at −20°C for 1 month.
Wash the cells with PBS and permeabilize cells with 40 μg/mL digitonin diluted in PBS on ice for 5 min.
Note: The purpose of permeabilizing cells before fixation is to remove soluble proteins for clearer observation of IBs.
Wash the cells with cold PBS and immediately incubated them with 4% PFA for 20 min at 25°C.
Permeabilize the cells again with 50 μg/mL digitonin diluted in PBS at 25°C for 10 min.
Block the cells with 10% FBS diluted in PBS at 25°C for 1 h.
Incubate with primary antibodies diluted in 10% FBS at 25°C for 1 h.
Note: Antibody dilution depends on the affinity of your antibody. In our experiment, dilution for LC3 antibody is 1:500, and for HA antibody recognizing HA-tagged candidate receptors is 1:500.
Wash the cells three times in PBS for 5 min each.
Incubate with secondary antibodies diluted in 10% FBS at 25°C for 1 h in dark.

Note: We used the Alexa Fluor 568 (1:500) for HA and Alexa Fluor 647 (1:500) for LC3. Other fluorescent secondary antibodies can also be used.
Wash the cells three times in PBS for 5 min each in dark.
Mount samples with a drop of ProLong Gold Antifade Mountant and dry at 25°C for 6–12 h in dark.
Confocal microscopy imaging.
Place the sample on the platform of a confocal microscope with a 60× objective (40×∼100× objectives are suitable). We used the Olympus FV3000 for imaging, other confocal microscopes (Nikon A1, Leica LSM780, etc) can also be used.
Find the cells under the eyepiece and switch to imaging mode.
Choose suitable channels: Alexa Fluor 405 for Q103-HTT-BFP, Alexa Fluor 568 for candidate receptors, and Alexa Fluor 647 for LC3.
Preview the image and adjust focal plane, laser intensity, HV (High Voltage), etc.
Note: The optimum layer for observing IBs may be different from cells. Try to find the focal plane that displays the clearest IBs.
Acquire fluorescence images for more than 50 IB-containing cells in each group.
Quantify the LC3 area around IBs following the steps in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1982-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Steps for quantifying LC3 area around IB with image J
Detailed steps to quantify LC3 area around IB with image J after obtaining images. Step-by-step instructions are listed in the figure.
Determine potential receptors for further study.
After obtaining the LC3 area around IBs from at least 50 IBs in each group, enter the results into GraphPad Prism.
Use unpaired T-test to analyze the difference between candidate receptor and control group.
Choose the proteins which can associate with IBs (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]) and recruit more LC3 around IBs compared to the control group (p<0.05) as potential receptors for further study.
Protein aggregates degradation
Timing: 3 days

After finding out potential receptors that associate with IBs and recruit more autophagosomes, we use a chase assay to explore the potential receptors’ effects on Q103-HTT degradation with cycloheximide (CHX) inhibition of protein synthesis. Caution that when co-expressing with other proteins, the expression level of Q103-HTT may change. In order to unambiguously compare the degradation level, adjust the amounts of Q103-HTT plasmids when transfecting cells to achieve similar initial expression level of Q103-HTT in each group.
CHX chase assay (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1982-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. A scheme of CHX chase assay
Transfect cells with Q103-HTT-GFP together with an empty plasmid or plasmids expressing candidate receptors. 24 h after transfection, add CHX and collect cells at indicated time. Perform immunoblot to analyze the amount of Q103 and candidate receptors.
Equally plate U2OS cells in 24-well plate at 105 cells / well. Each group needs four wells.
Transfect cells with Q103-HTT-GFP together with an empty plasmid or plasmids expressing potential receptors.
24 h after transfection, treat cells with 50 μg/mL CHX, with or without 0.5 μg/mL Bafilomycin A1 as indicated.
Collect cells at indicated time points, lyse in 200 μL Aggregates loading buffer and boil at 100°C for 10 min.
Immunoblot and analyzing.
Load 10 μL/sample into 10% PAGE gel and conduct SDS-PAGE as conventional methods (a constant voltage of 80 V for stacking gel and 120 V for separating gel).
Transfer proteins to 0.45 μm PVDF membranes. We recommend wet transfer method with a constant current of 300 mA for 90 min. The transfer buffer should be pre-cold at 4°C, and the transfer tank should be placed in ice bath.
Block membrane with 5% non-fat milk in TBST for 30 min at 25°C.
Wash membranes three times with TBST.
Incubate with primary antibodies diluted in TBST at 4°C for 12 h.

Note: Antibody dilution depends on the affinity of your antibody. In our experiment, dilution for GFP antibody recognizing Q103-HTT-GFP is 1:5,000, for HA antibody recognizing HA-tagged candidate receptors is 1:2,000, for RPN1 antibody is 1:5,000. RPN1 is used as internal control. Other controls such as β-actin and GAPDH can also be used.
Wash membranes three times with TBST for 5 min each.
Incubate with secondary antibodies diluted in TBST for 1 h at 25°C.
Wash membranes three times with TBST for 5 min each.
Detect immunoreactivity with Western Blot ECL chemiluminescent substrates and capture images by ChemiDoc imaging system (Bio-Rad).
Quantify each band under the same threshold in ImageJ.
Calculate the ratio of GFP over RPN1 for each sample and normalize to the initial value (time point 0) within each group. The decreased values reflect the degradation of Q103-HTT.
